importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was updated, indicating the latest information on Kansei Matsuzawa's achievement in college football.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current time frame of the article, indicating that the events described (such as the game against Stanford) occurred in the 2025 NCAA season.

keyTakeAways: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old from Ichikawa, Japan, made a historic 38-yard game-winning field goal in the opening weekend of the NCAA college football season, giving the University of Hawaii a 23-20 victory over Stanford.

Matsuzawa had no formal coaching or English proficiency in Japan, and learned to kick football by watching YouTube videos of NFL players, including Seattle Seahawks kicker Jason Myers, who reached out to him on Instagram.

The story highlights Matsuzawa’s personal journey: from failing an exam in Japan to pursuing dreams in the US, where he worked at a steakhouse, cut his own hair to save money, and improved his English through study at Hocking College.
Matsuzawa received a scholarship to the University of Hawaii, a moment that emotionally moved both him and his coach, Thomas Sheffield, who praised his resilience and self-driven ambition.
He is inspired by baseball superstar Shohei Ohtani, modeling his mindset and preparation on Ohtani’s discipline and excellence.
Matsuzawa aims to play in the NFL, becoming the first Japanese national to do so, and has set a goal of playing 10 seasons and winning a Super Bowl.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Matsuzawa looks to Ohtani’s discipline, preparation, and mindset as a benchmark for his own performance and career goals.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old placekicker from Ichikawa, Japan, made a historic game-winning 38-yard field goal in the opening weekend of the NCAA college football season, securing a 23-20 victory for the University of Hawaii over Stanford. Despite having no formal coaching or English skills in Japan, Matsuzawa taught himself how to kick by watching YouTube videos of NFL players, including Seattle Seahawks kicker Jason Myers, who even reached out to him on Instagram. His journey includes overcoming personal setbacks, such as failing an exam and losing motivation, and working hard in Japan—like waitressing and cutting his own hair to save money—before receiving a scholarship to Hocking College in Ohio, where he improved his English. He later joined the University of Hawaii, where he is supported by coach Thomas Sheffield, who praises his resilience and self-driven determination. Inspired by Japanese baseball star Shohei Ohtani, Matsuzawa now dreams of joining the NFL, becoming the first Japanese national to do so, and achieving long-term success including a Super Bowl win and a 10-year professional career.
title: The NFL hopeful from Japan who learned to kick on YouTube
